title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1 Assignment
Load the table random_vars.rds and get an overview of what it contains with View(random_vars)

random_vars <- readRDS("../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
View(random_vars)


For each variable, compute the following values.

expected value
variance
standard deviation



#  1. Expected value
expected_value_age <- mean(random_vars$age)
expected_value_income <- mean(random_vars$income)
cat("expected_value_age:", expected_value_age, "\n","expected_value_income :",expected_value_income ,"\n")

#> expected_value_age: 33.471 
#>  expected_value_income : 3510.731

# 2. variance

variance_age <- var(random_vars$age)
variance_income <- var(random_vars$income)
cat("variance_age :",variance_age ,"\n" ,"variance_income :",variance_income,"\n")

#> variance_age : 340.6078 
#>  variance_income : 8625646

# 3. standard deviation

sd_age <- sd(random_vars$age)
sd_income <-  sd(random_vars$income)
cat("sd_age :",sd_age ,"\n","sd_income :",sd_income,"\n")

#> sd_age : 18.45556 
#>  sd_income : 2936.945



Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations?

The standard deviation is a measure of the spread or dispersion of values around the mean. Here we have the variables that have different units: age and income. Age is typically measured in years, while income is measured in currency. Since these variables have different units, direct comparison of their standard deviations may not be meaningful.

Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute:

covariance
correlation


# Compute covariance and correlation
covariance <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)
correlation <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)

cat("covariance :",covariance ,"\n","correlation :",correlation,"\n")

#> covariance : 29700.15 
#>  correlation : 0.5479432


What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation ?

The correlation is easier to interpret because it is a standardized measure that ranges between -1 and 1. Covariance is not as easy to interpret as correlation primarily because it is influenced by the original units of the variable.

Compute the conditional expected value for:

E[income|age <= 18]
E[income|age ∈(18, 65)]
E[income|age >= 65]



# 1. E[income|age <= 18]
conditional_expected_value_1 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age <= 18])

# 2. E[income|age ∈(18, 65)]
conditional_expected_value_2 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age >= 18 & random_vars$age < 65])

# 3. E[income|age >= 65]
conditional_expected_value_3 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age >= 65])

cat(" conditional_expected_value_1",conditional_expected_value_1,"\n","conditional_expected_value_2",conditional_expected_value_2,"\n","conditional_expected_value_3",conditional_expected_value_3)

#>  conditional_expected_value_1 389.6074 
#>  conditional_expected_value_2 4685.734 
#>  conditional_expected_value_3 1777.237

title: Probability Theory
text:
Let T = on time
\(\bar{T}\\\)= not on time
S = change in scope
\(\bar{S}\\\)= no change in scope

From the figure, we know that,
P(S)= 0.3
P(T/S) = 0.2
P(\(\bar{T}\\\)/S)= 0.8
p(\(\bar{S}\\\)) = 0.7
P(T/\(\bar{S}\\\))= 0.6
P(\(\bar{T}\\\)/\(\bar{S}\\\))= 0.4
Using above we can compute below:

\(P(T\cap S) = P(T/S) \cdot P(S) = 0.2*0.3 = 0.06\)
\(P(T \cap \bar{S}\\) = P(T/\bar{S}\\) \cdot P(\bar{S}\\) = 0.6*0.7 = 0.42\)
\(P(\bar{T} \cap {S}\\) = P(\bar{T}\\/S) \cdot P(S)\\ = 0.8*0.3 = 0.24\)
\(P(\bar{T} \cap \bar{S} \\) = P(\bar{T}\\/\bar{S}\\) \cdot P(\bar{S}\\) = 0.4*0.7 = 0.28\)

sum of all probabilities = 0.06+0.42+0.24+0.28 = 1



# Given probabilities
prob_S <- 0.3
Prob_T_given_S <- 0.2
Prob_Tbar_given_S <- 0.8
prob_Sbar <- 0.7
Prob_T_given_Sbar <- 0.6
Prob_Tbar_given_Sbar <- 0.4

# Calculating required probabilities
Prob_T_and_S <- Prob_T_given_S * prob_S
Prob_T_and_Sbar <- Prob_T_given_Sbar * prob_Sbar
Prob_Tbar_and_S <- Prob_Tbar_given_S * prob_S
Prob_Tbar_and_Sbar <- Prob_Tbar_given_Sbar * prob_Sbar


# Print the result
cat("P(T ∩ S) =", Prob_T_and_S, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S) = 0.06

cat("P(T ∩ S') =", Prob_T_and_Sbar, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S') = 0.42

cat("P(T' ∩ S) =", Prob_Tbar_and_S, "\n")

#> P(T' ∩ S) = 0.24

cat("P(T' ∩ S') =", Prob_Tbar_and_Sbar, "\n")

#> P(T' ∩ S') = 0.28

# Sum 

cat("Sum=", Prob_T_and_S+Prob_T_and_Sbar+Prob_Tbar_and_S+Prob_Tbar_and_Sbar, "\n")

#> Sum= 1

# Given probabilities
prob_S <- 0.3
Prob_T_given_S <- 0.2
Prob_Tbar_given_S <- 0.8
prob_Sbar <- 0.7
Prob_T_given_Sbar <- 0.6
Prob_Tbar_given_Sbar <- 0.4

# Calculating required probabilities
Prob_T_and_S <- Prob_T_given_S * prob_S
Prob_T_and_Sbar <- Prob_T_given_Sbar * prob_Sbar
Prob_Tbar_and_S <- Prob_Tbar_given_S * prob_S
Prob_Tbar_and_Sbar <- Prob_Tbar_given_Sbar * prob_Sbar


# Print the result
cat("P(T ∩ S) =", Prob_T_and_S, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S) = 0.06

#> P(T ∩ S') = 0.42

#> P(T' ∩ S) = 0.24

#> P(T' ∩ S') = 0.28

# Sum 

cat("Sum=", Prob_T_and_S+Prob_T_and_Sbar+Prob_Tbar_and_S+Prob_Tbar_and_Sbar, "\n")

#> Sum= 1

title: Probability Theory
text:
2.1 Source code

# Given percentages
P_Smartphone <- 42.3 
P_Tablet <- 27.8 
P_Computer <- 10 

P_Smartphone_and_Tablet_and_Computer <- 0.5 
P_Smartphone_and_Tablet <- 7.3 
P_Smartphone_and_Computer <- 8.8 
P_Computer_and_Tablet <- 3.3 

# Calculating percentages
P_all_three_devices <- P_Smartphone_and_Tablet_and_Computer
P_at_least_two_devices <- P_Smartphone_and_Tablet + P_Smartphone_and_Computer + P_Computer_and_Tablet+P_Smartphone_and_Tablet_and_Computer
P_only_one_device <- P_Smartphone + P_Computer + P_Tablet

# Printing results
cat("1. Percentage of customers using all three devices =", P_all_three_devices, "%\n")

#> 1. Percentage of customers using all three devices = 0.5 %

cat("2. Percentage of customers using at least two devices =", P_at_least_two_devices, "%\n")

#> 2. Percentage of customers using at least two devices = 19.9 %

cat("3. Percentage of customers using only one device =", P_only_one_device, "%\n")

#> 3. Percentage of customers using only one device = 80.1 %

title: Probability Theory
text:
3.1 Source code

# Given probabilities
P_B_given_A <- 0.97
P_B_given_Abar <- 0.01
P_A <- 0.04
P_Abar <- 1 - P_A
cat("P_Abar",P_Abar)

#> P_Abar 0.96

# Calculate the probability
P_Abar_given_B <- (P_B_given_Abar * P_Abar) / (P_B_given_Abar * P_Abar + P_B_given_A * P_A)
P_A_given_B <- (P_B_given_A * P_A) / (P_B_given_A * P_A + P_B_given_Abar * P_Abar)

#Display result
cat("1. Probability that when the alarm is triggered the product is found to be flawless =", P_Abar_given_B, "\n")

#> 1. Probability that when the alarm is triggered the product is found to be flawless = 0.1983471

cat("2. Probability that when the alarm is triggered the product is found to have flaws =", P_A_given_B, "\n")

#> 2. Probability that when the alarm is triggered the product is found to have flaws = 0.8016529

cat("These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.8% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.2% that the product is faulty.")

#> These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.8% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.2% that the product is faulty.
